body: @eirslett agreed
Added tests and a more complete screen shot. One glitch is that this causes the Annotations pane to show redundant info, as it has service listed already...

so I don't think this is shippable without revisions because it looks really chatty now. If this change was isolated to just the bottom part, or we took out the Service column in the top part, it would be shippable imho
I guess another option would be to change the code so that it didn't apply to both sections.
Yet anothet option could be to just add a service column at the bottom like there is at the top
Added a commit with one option, which is to make the top match the bottom. Here's a screenshot

LGTM!

> Adrian Cole @adriancole 12:50
> @eirslett on endpoint formatting..
> 150.151.152.153:0 vs 150.151.152.153?
> we have a test to show the former, but often zero is absence of a value (at least in code I've noticed)
> I can see it both ways, but kindof prefer just dropping port from the label when zero

No strong opinions here. Leaving it as it is (showing the zero) indicates that Zipkin is indeed able to show which port a service answered on - which can be handy for people to know, when they try to improve their instrumentation/pass in more data. (port, in this case)
lgtm. Thanks for improvements & tests. I was porting this change from our pre-JS fork where it was only affecting the bottom part.
Can you please post the JSON data here as text, not as images? It's a bit hard to type it in all over again...

ps to get the json, use http://your_host/api/v1/trace/_hex_trace_id_here_

http://zipkin.io/zipkin-api/#/paths/%252Ftrace%252F%257BtraceId%257D

Thanks Reply

This is unusual Trace picture.

I hope I can get your help, thank you.

Checking the data flow process, we found the results will be different if the root Span of ParentId to "" (empty string) or "00000000000000."
When the root Span parentId value is "0000000000000000", the display may produce strange errors, such as when the display can not find the root Span, but sometimes is normal.
Thank u.

That is correct; if it refers to a parent ID that doesn't exist, the UI logic fails. It recurses through all the spans, and if a parent ID is defined, it tries to find that span. If it's not there, things fail.

Sorry, that was a bad example, I missed the detection for endpoint. However, there's somewhere that it's not checking because it's crashing on me... 

Ah, CORE_ADDRESS: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-ui/js/component_ui/traceToMustache.js#L114
Yep, confirmed that it was a CLIENT_ADDR annotation. It appears that the value doesn't matter for CLIENT_ADDR, as it will always be overridden by the endpoint.

Ps the root span is when the parent is unset. 0 is not a special value (it
is a valid id!).

Please look into your instrumentation and correct it!

5.json is root span data, parent ID is the correct way to set (unset) :)

When I post 1.json data, trace is correct, but if then post 5.json data, found trace changes, the original Func1 had changed the timestamp:(

Hope to get your help, thank you：）
＝＝＝＝＝＝＝＝＝＝＝＝＝＝＝only 1.json ＝＝＝＝＝＝＝＝＝＝＝

When you say generated by these languages, can you be more specific? Do you know which libraries are in use (if open source)? Regardless, one of your questions was about timestamps. Zipkin corrects for clock-skew, if you add the query `?raw` to your api call, you can see the data without any adjustments.

Ex. `http://your_host/api/v1/trace/493e8314428aa606?raw`

Sorry the tips are a bit vague. I'm displaced and can't look too deeply into this for a day or two.

I have found the reason, the problem is the data we generate, it has been corrected
*Performs clock-skew method when the root span only have cr and cs timestamp.

I love the idea of making the UI customizable.

Another way would be bringing in features like this in a configurable way, linking to the discussion of the trade-offs involved. This approach could nicely support bringing in features from forks: keep the default experience consistent and always correct, but let users choose their trade-offs. Of course that adds overhead in maintenance, or rather instability; we'll never ever test all 600 combinations of feature flags. Initially I'd solve that by adding cautionary comments and documentation. Over time we could start supplying well-tested configuration presets.

All in all, I'm not sure it's a good trade-off, but it's a nice idea to play with.
Agree. I'm for closing this and creating new issue(s) to track the logistics work.

zipkin-web is a dumb proxy and unnecessary.

You don't need to run it because the javascript is now hosted on the query
server which defaults to port 9411. This port can be changed with the
QUERY_PORT variable.

Per various communication, the code here is not going to be maintained, so
I would recommend transitioning to the new server. You will get better
support from me and others, as well better documentation and a better
server.

so here's an idea. Right now, the only code that's needed and not in zipkin-java is zipkin-ui. 

## Preparation: move zipkin-ui to zipkin-java and stop development here

Regardless, first step we should take is move zipkin-ui to zipkin-java and stop affecting master here:
1. Merge pull requests and cut a final release of zipkin-ui here
2. Migrate zipkin-ui to zipkin-java repo (via `git filter-branch` and friends to preserve history)
   - implies converting the build script to the maven alternative
3. cut zipkin-ui from the zipkin-java repo

At this point, everything is in sync and we have a couple options to proceed.

## Option 1: shuffle repository names

The simplest option would be to rename zipkin to something else (zipkin-archived or zipkin-legacy) and then rename zipkin-java to zipkin.

### Pros
- no chance to screw up forks (they basically can continue off master and/or be abandoned)
- irrelevant issues and old pull requests aren't imported to the new codebase
- current issues in zipkin-java are retained

### Cons
- Not sure if the rename shuffle will work or not. Ex can you rename a github repository to a historical name of another?
- Some issues like UI ones, or the new model will need to be recreated
- zipkin-java has less stars and watchers.
  - These would need to be organically regrown
- zipkin-java has less collaborators.
  - Folks who've done historical work in zipkin won't show up in the commit log until they do more work.

## Option 2: git-fu

Another approach would be to rename master to scala, push master from the java codebase, then turn off zipkin-java

### Pros
- zipkin stars, watchers, and collaborator stats remain in place
- issues that don't relate to the scala implementation don't need to be recreated.

### Cons
- folks with existing forks off master on either side will be disrupted
  - The act of turning off zipkin-java abandons relevant forks off the current codebase
  - The act of renaming master here disrupts any forks off the old codebase
- closed pull requests and issues have little to do with the current codebase or build.
  - Basically search is irrelevant, as most issues will refer to things that never affected the java port, ex finagle, scrooge, anorm, sbt, gradle...

---

#### Adrian's vote: Option 1: shuffle

The more I think about it, the less I like option 2. I feel it disrupts both sides with technical gotchas. While I do like the idea of memorializing past contributions and stars, I hope we've made a project that people will star again, and contribute to again. I'll certainly continue to contribute effort to the socializing of zipkin such that stars might be reborn faster. I'd also offer effort to recreate issues that are still relevant.

- zipkin-java: @sveinnfannar @dsyer @abesto @eirslett @michaelsembwever

The second con is a bit questionable, as there may be many things in closed issues that shed light as to why certain things are done one way or another, especially if java impl just copied the original logic. But I hardly ever used search on the old issues/PRs, so I'm not the right person to judge that.

zipkin-java repo is far better documented than the old ones, and the pull

there are some good issues in the old repo, the majority are not going to
ease understanding of the new codebase. If given a choice, I'd stick with
the ones that directly caused the current codebase.
I'm voting for yurishkuro's solution! The variant of 2.

So to be clear, the git-fu would be something like this..

``` bash
# after git tag 1.40.2 is pushed and released.. we have a cease-fire on the repo

# First, from zipkin repo, rename master to scala
$ git branch -m master scala
$ git push origin scala

# Now, from zipkin-java repo, push master to the zipkin repo
$ git remote add zipkin https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin.git
$ git push -f zipkin master

# Next, from the zipkin repo, fix travis credentials and cut a patch release to test it
```

The JSON should be whatever was retrieved from the call to `/api/v1/traces/XXX`, as it's the same object.
@yurishkuro you have this feature already.. do you default to raw json? any thoughts about what the default should be?

### config.json

When config.json is missing, it's a completely blank screen, with text to the effect of

```
Error loading config.json: server error (Bad Gateway)
```

The rationale for this is that [the mechanism for showing the entire UI](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-ui/js/main.js#L9) relies on config.json, so if it's not there then loading the UI doesn't make sense. Typically you only run into this with a misconfiguration anyways -- but right now, you get a blank page, which is confusing. This is better than a blank page.

This can be triggered by running `npm run dev` without launching a zipkin query server.

### ajax errors

Screenshot for bad gateway (this can be triggered by runnning `npm run dev` without launching a zipkin server, just make sure to add a `{}` to `static/config.json` so you don't trigger the config.json error instead).

![span_loads](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/567900/15662246/cf6cc5e2-26bc-11e6-8867-7031e1edc63a.png)

### query errors

Screenshot for bad query such as `foo==bar`... the error message could be better if the query server returned a better message. That's something for a future PR.
![bad_query](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/567900/15662250/de06695a-26bc-11e6-86a0-fba16a653d1a.png)

TL;DR I feel your pain, as I've mentioned this myself a couple times. However, the route isn't to ask the entire zipkin ecosystem to change to adopt this format. The following issue is tracking this https://github.com/spring-cloud/spring-cloud-sleuth/issues/253

There are good reasons for spring-cloud-stream to envelope data, because it is trying to do things portable across different messaging transports. This isn't a good enough reason to muddy zipkin's data format.

For example, this data has nothing to do with the payload, intentionally! There's also no cross-language tool that shares this format. In other words, we'd be special-casing spring-cloud-stream, but impacting several languages who don't have a tool that reads this, and probably couldn't be runtime portable with spring-cloud-stream. In other words, this is the wrong way to look at the problem.

I'd explore some way of making sleuth/stream send zipkin formatted messages to a dedicated zipkin topic. For example, sending in a way that doesn't require affecting the payload. If that isn't possible, another option would be to add a KafkaZipkinSpanReporter, referencing the one in brave.

https://github.com/openzipkin/brave/blob/master/brave-spancollector-kafka/src/main/java/com/github/kristofa/brave/kafka/KafkaSpanCollector.java

Kafka reporters in any language are <100 lines of code, and it is normal case in zipkin to expect transports such as http, scribe and kafka to not share the actual transport code or metadata. What does work is sharing a data format, so we should focus on how to achieve that.
